newsitem.title: REPUBLIC OF IRELAND: Ulster TV says expects a better year in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Ulster TV says expects a better year in 1997.

text.p: Ulster Television Plc said on Wednesday that it expects a better year in 1997 with improving economic indicators, particularly the widely expected increased growth in consumer expenditure.
The company said 1996 was proving to be a difficult year for ITV with regard to advertising revenue, although there were some significant regional variations.

"The short-term market remains slow and, for the year as a whole, we continue to expect that ITV is likely to achieve an overall year-on-year increase in line with inflation," Chairman J.B.McGuckian said in a results statement.
"We expect to achieve a broadly similar outcome, thus consolidating our market share of ITV revenue at around the two percent level," he added.
Ulster TV said operaring costs for the second half of 1996 are not expected to vary significantly from the corresponding period in 1995.
"Investment income will be lower following the 10.5 million sterling special dividend paid on July 1 this year, thus reducing future income from short-term deposits," said McGuckian.
Earlier, Ulster TV announced a 27 percent rise in pre-tax profits to 4.67 million pounds sterling for the six-months to June 30.
Advertising revenue, which accounts for more than 95 percent of turnover, increased by 2.6 percent over the corresponding period in 1995.

Ulster TV said it had increased its share of total television viewing in Northern Ireland during the six-month period by 0.7 percent to 41.4 despite the increasing accessibility and number of new television channels.
ITV experienced a decline of two percentage points to 35.3 percent, it said.

With the introduction of cable television to Northern Ireland, the growth of satellite television and the imminent arrival of digital television services, new opportunities were emerging, the company said.

"We will continue to investigate and evaluate these, with a view to developing new revenue streams in areas where we can use our experience and skills and which are complimentary to our core broadcasting and programme-producing operation," McGuckian said.
Ulster TV said it was presently assessing feasibility of introducing new programme services on its guaranteed digital spectrum allocation following the the introduction of the 1996 Broadcasting Act.
The Act introduced a legislative and regulatory framework for the development of digital terrestrial televison and also further liberalising the restrictions on media and cross-media ownership.
The company said the ownership provisions will make possible further consolidation within ITV as well as greater ownership integration between newspapers and television.
